title.narrative: We Effect Mayakvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt på landsbygden
We Effect Rural Mayan Women’s Economic Empowerment

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Utvecklingsinsatsen syftar till att minska fattigdom bland ursprungsbefolkningar i fyra territorier på landsbygden i Guatemala genom ett fokus på kvinnors ekonomiska egenmakt och förebyggande av könsbaserat våld. Totalt förväntas 7500 ekonomiska initiativ sammansatta och ledda av kvinnor få tillgång till tekniskt och finansiellt stöd, förbättrad tillgång till lokala, regionala och nationella marknader. We Effect samarbetar med tio lokala organisationer i implementeringen av projektet under åren 2016-2020.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 This intervention aims to reduce poverty and violence on indigenous people, particularly Mayan women in four territories of Guatemala, promoting Women´s Economic Empowerment, through strengthening their capacities on productive technical matters and entrepreneurship; strengthening the peasant organizations capacities to ensure their response to their members to reduce poverty and strengthening advocacy work. The project also aims to improve market access and position of rural Mayan women within a framework of organizational strengthening and deepening knowledge of rights and demands for rights compliance, recognizing that economic empowerment ensures sustainable individual, collective and political empowerment.
The State and other actors contribute to rights holders’ poverty and violence reduction, especially for indigenous women in four rural territories of Guatemala.

tag.narrative: 1.1 - By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, currently measured as people living on less than $1.25 a day.
1.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa den extrema fattigdomen för alla människor överallt. Med extrem fattigdom avses för närvarande människor som lever på mindre än 1,25 US-dollar per dag.
2.1 - By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.

2.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa hunger och garantera alla människor, i synnerhet de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer, inklusive små barn, tillgång till tillräckligt med säker och näringsrik mat året om.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Main achieved results: -PODEEIR project focuses on promoting women´s economic empowerment in a holistic way. The project promotes processes seeking equal rights and creates productive and economic opportunities specially for poor rural indigenous women so that they can improve their living conditions. Besides promotes gender-based violence prevention and contributes to streghthen social organization. -Women participating in the project and their organizations have become more aware that violence against women and inequalities that they face are not something natural, it is something that can be eradicated. Now women feel more empowered to claim their economic, political and social rights. Women participaton in productive activities that were previously only intended for men has been an important change. Nowadays women have their own productive enterprises and are participate in local markets with their good quality products,which gives them opportunities to increase their income and possibilities to influence on decision making within their home and community. Changes are also taking place in terms of practices and customs about relegating women to domestic sphere. - Around 67 productive enterprises created by 4,928 women in 145 rural communities contribute to increase Women income and improve the families and communities access to healthy food. The partner organizations, have created spaces for women and men participation in decision-making and access to productive assets. Women formed into groups are participating in the economic sphere, as producers, generating income, and doing business. Taking into account that in acountry like Guatemala with a lot of inequality and a very patriarchal culture, these are considered important changes. -Within the emergency measures adopted to contain the Covid-19 pandemic, access to communities was closed, which limited commercialization of products, and caused crop losses and food shortages. However, in some way, the project's target groups, having their own food production in their communities, had for self-consumption and to sell or exchange with their neighbors, so it can be said that target groups that are in a situation of vulnerability, are having a certain capacity for response and are resilient to economic crises such as those that the pandemic is causing. -It is important to mention that the counterpart not only promotes access to economic resources for the target groups, but rather, it makes a comprehensive approach to the empowerment of people with an approach based on human rights. We Effect starts from the premise that poverty is not only a lack of resources but also a lack of power. Therefore, in order to change this condition, actions such as strengthening of community organization, training, awareness, technical and financial support, have been promoted that help women have the power to influence making decisions that have to do with improving their living conditions at the family level, within their organizations and communities. Likewise, actions on gender-based violence prevention are promoted. The target groups, both men and women, have knowledge and tools about how violence against women can be prevented, the types of violence that exist and the importance of women's participation in the development of their communities. In times of the COVID-19 pandemic, violence against women has increased, so local radio campaigns on addressing violence against women have been implemented, among other actions. -To reduce the work overload that women experience, the project promotes the distribution of household chores. As a result, of 5128 women, 25% report positive changes in the distribution of tasks within their household and have more time to devote to other activities for their benefit. (This data was collected through surveys and focus groups as part of the final evaluation of the project). -As a result of financial literacy training, women are more confident in accessing loans to invest in their businesses and create savings. Likewise, they have a greater capacity to perform investment calculations and profits from their ventures. -Cultivation techniques and methods are introduced for natural resources sustainable management, such as reforestation, gray water management, elaboration of organic compost, insecticides, pesticides and foliar plants for agroecological production, among others.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
